values:
...Bram Tchaikovsky turned up on those late-night stations, leaving me with a fondness for bands with no discernible lead guitar.  I woke up this morning with "Girl of My Dreams" stuck in my head:

<lj-embed id="11"/>

So obviously intended to be about a centerfold, so easily construed to be about a blow-up doll.
What if someone called in to work joyous?
Why would someone go to the trouble to make up hell?

The National Zoo's spectacled bear recently dropped a pair of cubs, and the Zoo has thoughtfully provided a video feed of Teh Cute. This has unsurprisingly sucked a substantial amount of time around here. During last night's episode, some of the action led us to wonder about the precise arrangement of the bear's nursing tackle, so I unthinkingly entered the search term "bear nipples." Yow.
The artist formerly known as IOZ: What, after all, is a drone strike if not a drive-by shooting?

via Slashdot an ex-TSA screener's blog: I recall one time I did a bag check on a man from Detroit, once the auto-making capital of the world. Having been informed by the x-ray operator that there was a bottle of water in the bag, I pulled it out and quickly sensed that something was slightly off. Then, I realized what it was: there was an enormous dildo rubber-banded to it. I then had an epiphany, spreading over me like a sunrise, beautiful and exhilarating: he wanted me to have to deal with the dildo. He did it on purpose. In rubber-banding that dildo to the water bottle he knew we would target, he seemed to say:

“Yes, I have a dildo, federal officer. Even after the horrors of 9/11, I am still alive; full of vitality, love, sex and, later tonight, that large dildo rubber-banded to the water you are about to confiscate from me. That bottle of water, bought with hard-earned American dollars to relinquish my bodily fluids, so as to make me strong and keep the wheels of commerce of this great nation turning. In taking my water, I want you, federal officer, to know that the terrorists have won, and that you are complicit. I want you to see my dildo. To hold it in your hand; to know that I, as well as my fellow passengers and countrymen, are strong and resilient.

That we, the people of this great nation, can, and will, snap back, like that rubber band.” Plenty more where that came from.

A neat blog I stumbled on (oops) mulls a concept I - and probably most public-educated folks - have frequently mulled:

[...]
Take, for example, Shakespeare. How many millions of people are turned away from recognizing his genius by having him stuffed down their throats at school at an age when they are not yet receptive to his language and psychological insights? Wouldn’t he be even more widely and highly regarded if people were to discover him for themselves, rather than be prejudiced against him by school?
Similarly, millions are turned off of maths and science by terrible teachers.
[...]

If the Presidential campaign seems vacuous to you, that’s because it is. Here are some questions that “we” — by which I mean the legacy party campaigns, their enablers, and our famously free press — can’t seem to bring ourselves to ask during the campaign. ...

One more thing: A friend once told me that he thought -- knew, actually -- that Alan Ruck's character Cameron was obviously fucking Ferris' girlfriend behind his back. Next time you see the move, pay close attention to Cameron and Sloane. You'll never unsee it.

https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2012/01/02/us/you-cut-the-defense-budget.html?src=tp

I bagged $1.05 trillion.

Not the opinion, etc.
If you keep picking it, it will never heal.

Today marks ten years as a civil servant (observed). In the current entry in , Sam and his officemates:

[...] read over this paper of my Lord Keeper's, wherein are laid down the faults of the Navy, so silly, and the remedies so ridiculous, or else the same that are now already provided, that we thought it not to need any answer, the Duke of York being able himself to do it: that so it makes us admire the confidence of these men to offer things so silly, in a business of such moment. But it is a most perfect instance of the complexion of the times!

A useful reminder about why I shouldn't be such a candy-ass about writing and publishing.
...and I remain the most fortunate of men.

I was going to fry chicken tonight in some of the surplus bacon grease 's food paradigm shift has generated, but Whole  Foods had fresh whole wheat tortillas, so I tried out a recent notion.

I filmed a cookie sheet with some of the aforementioned grease, dashed some seasoned salt on it, then put chicken thighs on the sheet skin-up, then put everything into a cold oven set to 450F, with the timer set for forty minutes. When the oven hit four-fifty, I sprinkled some more seasoning on top of the chicken, then ignored it until the timer went off. I broke loose the thighs and the fond with a spatula, put the cookie sheet on an incline, and left the thighs and salvaged crusty goodness to rest and drain about five minutes.

Come time to eat, for each tortilla I took one thigh, removed and reserved the skin, and raked the meat off the bone. the meat went on the tortilla, followed by salsa, topped with the skin and a ration of pan goo. My Vision was for salsa verde, but my Vision turned out to be rubbish, or maybe the salsa was. Anyway, garlic-chile Cholula hot sauce turned out to be a better choice.

Nom. I will do it again

I just spotted the first pair of man-jeggings near 15th&P.

Actually, he seemed to be making it work. I don't know what that says about who.

Baby anteater communique'.

Head-asplodin' cute, but I'm kind of concerned about the numerous hints that the (premature) pup may be, uh, special.

I wish this aside from Will Wilkinson didn't resonate with me:

I’ve been thinking seriously of making a number of cartoon dialogues on divisive questions because, ironically enough, I think the comic book format is capable of a less cartoonish examination of hard questions than one normally encounters in documentaries.

I'm reading the new Girl Genius novelization, and it works better than I'd have thought. The literary-fiction types who always go on about "show, don't tell" should probably take their meds before opening the book, but I've always thought that main thing following that maxim too closely gets you is an MFA in creative writing.

IOZ shows us how to write a movie review:

...Yet not once do we see Natalie Portman's Nina Sayers enjoy herself. Nowhere are we permitted some brief glimpse of the joy of great performance. Oh, what, is she doing it because of her central-casting stage mother? Um, Darren, what's my motivation? You're crazy, Natalie. That's your motivation. Now, hold still while we apply this blood to your naked body. Look, even Peter Shaffer, a playwright with the emotional insight of a goldfish whose owner left a book of Freud case studies open on the credenza beside the tank, figured out that Doomed-Genius Composer© Mozart really fucking liked music, was transported by it, was an instrument of a sort of divinity, whose own soul resonated with the notes. Prima ballerina Natalie Portman is an instrument, all right, like a fleshlight....

Oktoberfest:

One hearing aid was ... found, as were a leather whip, a live rabbit, a tuba, a ship in a bottle, 1,450 items of clothing, 770 identity cards, 420 wallets, 366 keys, 330 bags and 320 pairs of glasses, 90 cameras and 90 items of jewellery and watches.

A total of 37 children were also lost.

Not bad, averaged over 7,000,000 liters of beer.

[via Andrew Sullivan]

It's safe to assume the anxiety industry will celebrate its Christmas with all due fervor today.  As long as everyone's going back to the well, I'll re-repost what Jim Henley wrote a couple of years ago; I don't think anyone's managed to improve on it:

But the tendency to want to turn the anniversary into some kind of national day of mourning [...] is decadent, an indulgence. For one thing, it risks making a holiday out of The Day America Got Its Ass Kicked. Let’s face it: for all the justified gratitude toward firefighters and police in two American cities, "9/11" represents a spectacular failure of the United States government  [...] I don’t want to be Serbia, forever memorializing some church that got vandalized seven hundred years ago. At some point America needs to stop picking the national scab. If we’re going to have ceremonies every year, hold the big ones in Shanksville, and remind ourselves that it was only ordinary people who behaved with distinction that day. Politicians who wish to appear at the ceremony will be allowed to read from a prepared script reading, in its entirety, "Sorry."

The prospect of tenth-anniversary observances fills me with horror.  If we've got to have an institutionalized observance, the current way we're doing it makes us cogs in the perpetual-grievance machine that powers terrorism in the first place. If people just have to commemorate 9/11, I wish they'd do it by repudiating that outlook, that machine: make fart jokes, make love, build something.

"I have stood your meanness as long as I intend to. You have played the part of a damned scoundrel, and are a coward, and if you were any part of a man I would slap your jaws and force you to resent it. You may as well not issue any orders to me, for I will not obey them, and I will hold you personally responsible for any further indignities you endeavor to inflict upon me."

--N.B. Forrest to Braxton Bragg, uh, sometime during the Civil War.
Just started the new Heinlein bio.  Now I remember that I found the author's earlier RAH books annoying for flourish-y writing and a poor command of illustrative detail.

Yves Smith has fun with a Wall Street Journal article that wonders why employers can't get worthwhile employees at lowball wages after spending a generation undermining conditions for stable employment:

Quaint as it may sound, there once was a tacit commitment: a worker who competent and dedicated could expect to spend a considerable amount of his career at with one firm (in the 1980s, job tenures of less than five years needed to be justified). But as cost cutting and short term earnings fixation became more pervasive, average time of employment shortened greatly. And with that came a major shift in behavior: it made less and less sense for employers to hire talented people with good general competence and character and train them. They’d be unlikely to recoup the cost of the investment. Instead, companies started more and more to seek staff, in that horrid corporate cliche, who could hit the ground running. For instance, headhunters would increasingly be tasked to find someone who was doing exactly the same job at a competitor firm. This tendency goes all the way down the food chain; for instance, I’m told it’s impossible to become a bartender in NYC unless you have at least two years of bartending experience.

sifts the memes so I don't have to:

Rules: Don't take too long to think about it. Fifteen albums that you've listened to that will always stick with you or influenced you, the ones that touch you and you can listen to again and again from start to finish. First fifteen you can recall in no more than 15 minutes.

[in quasi-alphabetical order, as filed on our CD shelves:]

1. Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass: Whipped Cream and Other Delights
2. The Blacks, Dolly Horrorshow
3. Neko Case, Furnace Room Lullaby
4. Elvis Costello, Trust (anything from My Aim Is True to King of America, really)
5. Devo, Q: Are We Not Men A: We are Devo (anything before Shout, really)
6. Huun-huur-tu, 60 Horses in My Herd
7. Nitty Gritty Dirt Band et al., Will the Circle Be Unbroken?
8. Pretenders, Pretenders
9. Shonen Knife, Let's Knife
10. Southern Culture on the Skids, Dirt Track Date
11. Talking Heads, Talking Heads: 77
12. The Waitresses, Wasn't Tomorrow Wonderful?
13. Dance Craze, soundtrack
14. Repo Man, soundtrack
15. Jesus Christ Superstar, London cast recording, 1970

What with all this talk about Betelgeuse asploding on Facebook, a friend asked where to look.  I was at a loss for a description, since Orion is about the only constellation I can consistently identify given our cruddy urban starfield.  Googling around a bit, I found this really spiffy sky-mapper - maps to current time and geographic coordinates and gives horizon views.on demand.  Big win.

Is it just me, or is there a voguelet for newest-first comments going on out there?  

It is difficult for me to imagine a less helpful innovation in this context.

The artist formerly known as BarTel D'Arcy reminds me why I not only read Hit and Run, but still get Reason on paper with a bit on an anti-Islamic black-metal band in Beirut:

The band lives in and at least used to play in Beirut, so why hasn't some pious Lester Bangs managed to cap a thumbs-down review by, you know, murdering them? The only negative response of any note has been the inevitable "Against the Lebanon Anti-Islamic black metal 'Ayat' band" page on Facebook, which has a small number of followers (many with seemingly Christian names) and no content beyond the obvious: "Claimed to be the first 'Anti-Islamic Black Metal Band', they are not wanted in the Arab Islamic world."

Bonus H&R:

United Nations Names Iran to Commission on the Status of Women

Tim Cavanaugh pinpoints what's long bothered me formlessly about Matt Taibbi:

I understand Taibbi's appeal rests in large part on his style -- a combination of extreme dudgeon, over-the-top ad hominems and lotsa cussin' -- but I wish he would get out of his own way a little more. There's an interesting story in here, but in Taibbi's hurry to let you know that he's really really mad about stuff, the most interesting details get lost.

But it does sound like a good story.
ran the National Marathon in about 4:41!

[Freely adapted from Gloria Bley Miller, Thousand Recipe Chinese Cookbook, which I think I got from the Intimate Bookshop in Chapel Hill back when it was circling the drain and served as a remainder bin for the entire Southeast.  I always start from the assumption I'll need to double the seasoning in any given recipe.]

3lb. chicharrones (Salvadoran usage, inch-ish cubes of fatty pork shoulder, not fried pork skin);

Generous half-cup of soy sauce;
shot of brandy (no sherry in the larder);
squirt of honey from picturesque bear-shaped squeeze bottle;
water to cover meat;

4 cloves of garlic;
1 bunch scallions, sliced well up the green;
4-inch length of ginger root, fat but rather sloppily peeled.

Put meat and liquids in the pressure cooker, chopped the aromatics medium-fine in the food processor and added to the pot, cooked for about 35 minutes (wanted thirty, got side-tracked.).

Results were acceptable, but a little wimpy (despite doubling the garlic/ginger/scallion) and watery.  For next time:

--MOAR GARLIC; I seem to recall versions using lots of whole peeled cloves.
--More ginger.
--A little more scallion green.
--Less water: I used the trivet to prevent scorching, and I think I think I was misled by the deadspace.  The pressure cooker doesn't seem to reduce liquids as much as ambient simmering - I should rummage in Harold McGee or such to find out.  Probably about 25 minutes in the pressure cooker would be better.  Ultimately, this may just be a recipe for stove-top or oven braising as a matter of control.
--It's not in the recipe, but browning the meat might improve things; my imperfect understanding of red-cooking is that the soy sauce is supposed to stand in for browning, but maybe a belt'n'suspenders approach is called for.  Too bad, I liked the unfussy throw-it-in the-pot character of the technique.
--Also not in the recipe (did I miss something?), but converting the broth to a gravy with a cornstarch liaison might improve the dish.
--Probably needs more aggressive fat control, however much it pains me to write that.
--Could use a capsicum element, although not much.
--Damn, I meant to garnish it with the black sesame seeds I picked up on a whim awhile back.  Well, there's leftovers.
I just discovered that the screw holding the lid on my dutch oven is slotted for a butterknife.

Klaus Nomi for Jaegermeister.

[via the fine folks at Instaboner, who make me very happy.]

I stocked us up pretty well Friday (DC Disaster Hint: shop at the tienda, the clientele is less panicky than the Whole Foods crowd.) so it's been pretty much a matter of sitting still and reading. I've gotten through the second edition of John Guilmartin's Gunpowder and Galleys, which was even better than the 1974 original, a formative book for me when I encountered it in college.

Today's project was to turn a couple of pounds of flap meat that needed cooking into chile with black beans and roasted garlic. I started by roasting a couple heads of garlic and dicing a good-sized onion - both left over from the Thanksgiving dinner I didn't make on account of the flood - then cutting up the beef and browning it in small batches in lard. Once the beef was done, I sauteed the onions in the drippings and let them cool, then pureed them in the food processor. The beef went into the pressure cooker with a tomato base made with two cups of water (should have been three, I think), a 1.5oz tub of More Than Gourmet demiglace, and a 5oz can of tomato paste; a half-hour under pressure reduced the meat to shreds.  I added the pureed onion, a 2.5oz bottle of chile powder, two 15oz cans of black beans, and squished the garlic in, then mixed everything and simmered for a half-hour while farting around with the seasonings until I was happy: I ended up adding cumin, oregano, and various sorts of Hot Stuff, plus the juice of one and a half limes at the end to make it brighter. 

There were fewer leftovers to put away than I'd figured on, which I take for a sign of success.

Salami and egg salad:

--Boil three jumbo eggs.  There are many incredibly fussy egg-boiling algorithms, but throwing eggs into a disproportionate amount of cold water (about 1.5 gal/dozen), bringing them just to the boil, covering and switching off the heat, then ignoring them for a half-hour seems to involve the fewest moving parts.

--Dice the eggs, preferably in one of those piano-wire thingies.

--Dice 4oz salami.

--Combine the diced eggs and diced salami.  Add whopping great amounts of fresh black pepper if your salami isn't peppered already.

--Food-process the above all to the bejeezus.  Apply the way you would yer normal egg salad, except for the feeding-to-vegetarians part.
finished the Marine Corps Marathon in 4:41:10.  Yeehaw!

...maybe I can stop giving money to SLDN.

COL Om Prakash does the scholarship.

The Gurgling Cod passes along a landmark in industricational film. 

For maximum effect, imagine watching it in an imperfectly darkened fifth-period classroom and the 16mm print all scratched to hell.

What has been, for my modest purposes, the best bar in town is about to be evicted and sixteen people put out of work so that the Peace Corps can get an extra conference room. 

The world is full of nice beer and tasty cheeseburgers, but comfy places to consume them run by thoughtful people, not so much, and at the end of the week there will be one less.  Crap.

The Gurgling Cod:

The problem with Kimball, and what makes him think in this way, is the fundamental joylessness that permeates every corner of his enterprise. I use and like some of his recipes, but they generally emanate from a presumption that eating is a burden, and food is nasty, and only relentless experimentation can prevent you from failing as a cook by revealing the least intolerable way to prepare a given dish. If you doubt my argument, conduct the thought experiment of imagining the America's Test Kitchen Kama Sutra.

A dip into Amazon suggested that R. Crumb's illustrated Book of Genesis was finally out, so today's project (badly impeded by rain) was to see if it was available in any brick'n'mortar establishment.  I find it a bug-or-feature of urban life that I feel I ought to try and buy local if I can, short of being completely taken advantage of.

After coming up empty-handed on the first tranche of indie places, I stuck my head into the Borders at 14th & F, only to be completely bemused at where they'd put the thing if they stuck it into the revenue-heavy turf at the front of the store, the options being Fiction, Non-Fiction, Fantasy, Books You've Got to Read, Literature, Young Adult, Mystery and Thriller, Books for Your Funny Bone, and Biographies and Memoirs. 
 
Guess I'll try my luck in Dupont and Georgetown tomorrow if this %$#@! rain ever stops.

I can see putting six increments on the glute machine if you have such mighty hams that you've maxed out the 140-pound weight stack.

I can't see doing it with the pin in at thirty pounds.

I can see red when you do it and walk off and leave the machine that way.

The owners of my gym in Galveston had a placard on the wall that read: "IF YOU TOO WEAK TO RACK YOUR WEIGHTS YOU TOO WEAK TO LIFT!"* 

Damn straight.



*It was that kind of place. I hope they made it through Ike.
